data.title: Beyond The Square < Riverside Theatres
data.meta_description: Beyond the Square is Riverside Theatres’ drama access and inclusion workshop program for adults with disability. Workshops are an opportunity for people with disability to get involved in the performing arts. Participants explore and grow through drama, movement, music and imagination.
data.text:
Bob Deacon

Bob Deacon is a performer hailing from the town of Nyngan in Central Western NSW and is now based in the Inner West. He has a Diploma of Creative Arts and Health from the University of Tasmania and runs creative classes for people with a disability. He has performed stand-up comedy shows at the Sydney Comedy Festival, Sydney Fringe Festival, and the Adelaide Fringe Festival. His theatre credits include ‘Cosi’ with the Lane Cove Theatre Company, ‘Lady Windermere’s Fan’ with the Bondi & Eastern Suburb Theatre, ‘Tommy’ with the Mosman Musical Society, ‘Last Drinks’ with Brave New Word Theatre, as well as winning awards at Short + Sweet Festival.

Sophia Bila

Sophie Bila is a Teaching artist with experience working in both Film and Theatre. She has a strong passion for theatre and film as a medium for social change, education and imagining new possibilities through performance. She has worked in a variety of settings and contexts such as education and within community settings in the UK, South Africa and Australia as an applied theatre practitioner planning, delivering and facilitating workshops. Graduate from The Royal Central School of Speech and Drama in London, in Applied Theatre, Drama and Education. Teaching artist at Sydney Theatre Company with experience working on the School Drama programme, Connected, School Drama Virtual and Acting masterclasses. Prior to this she was an Actor and Stand up comedian in London. Currently she is working as a creative artist in theatre and also in film making.

Felicity Nicol

Felicity Nicol is an award-winning Performance Director and Artistic Director from Sydney, Australia. A graduate of the NIDA Director’s Course, she has gone on to work with prominent artists from around the world, including Ontroerend Goed (BEL), Punchdrunk; and, Gecko Physical Theatre (UK), Illutron (DEN) and Mammalian Diving Reflex (CAN). Felicity also holds a particular interest in working with young people, which has led her to working with Australian Theatre for Young People; and Spark Youth Theatre (AUS), Mit Ohnes Alles (GER), The Torontonians (CAN) and Company3 (UK).

Felicity’s mission as an artist is to interrupt our assumptions about people, and the world, in order to shift the cultural lens towards those who need it most. With this in mind, she has created work for 10 Nodi Festival (IT), Ruhrtriennale (GER), HAVEN Festival (DEN) and Wiener Festwochen (AUS). Felicity is a recipient of Australia Council for the Arts grants,Create NSW grants, a Mike Walsh Fellowship and the Sandra Bates Directors Award.

Her favourite career highlights include directing at The Sydney Opera House, creating a one-on-one performance for audiences in a moving car, and directing a non-verbal performative memorial via clowning, beer and a slide-show.
